Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandfather learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Situation2: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of the office a familiar comfort. As an architect, I prided myself on keeping projects moving, even if it meant checking in on progress with a casual glance, trusting my team to handle the details. But today, my phone buzzed with a message from my daughter: my grandson was struggling, caught in the middle of a crisis that left the whole family anxious. I knew, as a grandfather, I was expected to be present, to call, to offer reassurance and wisdom. Yet, deadlines loomed, and my team relied on my oversight to keep things on track. My mind raced between the expectation to be the steady hand at work and the loving support at home. I stared at the phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which call to answer first.
